html.p: What: Input events/rows from a lookup table

ol.li: Can be a CSV or KV store lookup
Often reading results of previous outputlookup
Can append to existing set of results or be the complete set of results

html.p: Why: Easy way to enrich the results set and provide context beyond the event data
So What: We'll use it a lot in this workshop and you'll use it a lot once you understand what it does

panel.html: We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup | inputlookup mydata.csv While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is: "_time",salesperson,"Cars Sold This Hour" 1711665905,Rich,1 1711665905,David,1 1711662305,Rich,0 1711662305,David,0 1711658705,Rich,1 1711658705,David,2 1711655105,Rich,2 1711655105,David,3

html.p: Have Splunk tell you what's in the csv file
Let's do something with that info
html.tt: | inputlookup mydata.csv | stats count as "Cars Sold" by salesperson

search.query: | inputlookup mydata.csv | stats count as "Cars Sold" by salesperson
